question: Paint is rust and moss green. Medieval colors -- Daddy's like an old knight. What about it? Freesia, freesia, everywhere. Daddy loves freesia -- and you, over there, lights. Not too bright. I'm looking for a saffron glow -- sort of tea- dance twenties.
answer: What do you think of all this, May? Oh, the President's got better things to do than come to my birthday party.

question: Daddy!
Have you got a minute?
answer: Not much more. Big day in the big city. What's on your mind?

question: Fireworks. Update -- we're con- structing the number '65' on the barge, archers from the State College at New Paltz will shoot flaming arrows at it, when it catches fire it will give us the effect of a Viking funeral with none of the morbidity... The Hudson River Authority says, for you, they'll make a special dispensation - of course there'll be an overtime bill for the Poughkeepsie Fire Dept...
answer: Allison, I trust you. This is your thing.

question: You've got patients waiting, I've got three hysterical chefs, one loves truffles, the other hates truffles, the third one doesn't know what truffles are. I'd better drive down.
Calm down, Daddy, you'll see, you're going to love it.
answer: Isn't it enough to be on this earth sixty-five years without having to be reminded of it.

question: Will you relax? I know it is a big deal day --
Drew told me.
I hope so.
Yeah. I guess so.
...This shit's not bad.
answer: -- The late harvest Riesling, Mr. Quince, a possibility for dessert.

question: And that?
answer: Pinot Grigio. We're considering it for the appetizer.

question: What do you do that for?
answer: Well sir, it's 9:30 in the morning.

question: Good morning, Drew. Thanks for coming out.
answer: Well, it's a big day. Wanted to line up a few ducks before kickoff. Any thoughts? Last minute refine- ments or variations?

question: 'Thoughts'? Not a one -- but I did hear a voice last night.
In my sleep.
'Yes'.
Maybe, who knows? You know how voices are. Let's go.
Good morning, Quince.
I'm doing great. You ready?
answer: I am, this is it. B Day.

question: How's that, Quince?
answer: Bontecou Day. Going to close with Big John -- Look at you, Bill, all cool as a cat and over at Bontecou's, I'll bet he's shitting in his pants.

question: Not my birthday again?
Thank God. Now could we go? Let's get this day started.
answer: I thought you were in a meeting--?

question: I am. With you.
I know it's none of my business --
answer: No, it's none of your business.

question: Do you love Drew?
answer: You mean like you loved Mom?

question: Forget about me and Mom -- are you going to marry him?
Don't get carried away.
Susan, you're a hell of a woman. You've got a great career, you're beautiful --
answer: And I'm your daughter and no man will ever be good enough for me.

question: Well, I wasn't going to say that --
answer: What were you going to say?

question: Listen, I'm crazy about the guy -- He's smart, he's aggressive, he could carry Parrish Communications into the 21st century and me along with it.
That's for me. I'm talking about you. It's not so much what you say about Drew, it's what you don't say.
Oh yes, I am. Not an ounce of excitement, not a whisper of a thrill, this relationship has all the passion of a pair of titmice.
Well, it worries me. I want you to get swept away. I want you to levitate. I want you to sing with rapture and dance like a dervish.
Be deliriously happy. Or at least leave yourself open to be.
answer: 'Be deliriously happy'. I'm going to do my upmost --

question: I know it's a cornball thing but love is passion, obsession, someone you can't live without. If you don't start with that, what are you going to end up with? I say fall head over heels. Find someone you can love like crazy and who'll love you the same way back. And how do you find him? Forget your head and listen to your heart. I'm not hearing any heart. Run the risk, if you get hurt, you'll come back. Because, the truth is there is no sense living your life without this. To make the journey and not fall deeply in love -- well, you haven't lived a life at all. You have to try. Because if you haven't tried, you haven't lived.
Aw, you're tough.
answer: I'm sorry. But give it to me again. The short version.

question: Stay open. Who knows? Lightning could strike.
answer: I won't. And when I tell Drew about it, he won't either.

question: You won't tell him, and even if you did, he'd clock it and punch it into his laptop in order to pull out some key phrases when he gives the Commencement Speech at Wharton.
I know. But I'm the only father you've got.
What?
answer: I was saying to Quince we won't need --

question: Did you just hear something?
answer: Why yes, Bill, I was saying to Quince --

question: What is it, Daddy --?
Are you okay?
answer: A-Okay. Got my gloves on, my ears pricked. I'm ready for action.

question: Well, go get 'em, Pops.
Yer damn right.
answer: ...Tomorrow we sign off -- photo opportunity, you and Big John, it'll lead network news. Okay so far?

question: Sounds good.
Do you think I need a haircut?
answer: Bill, after this deal, you'll be able to afford one. Their PR guy asked me, what did I think Parrish Communications stood for, that's principle and ethics- wise? I came up with something, but then it occurred to me, why don't I ask Bill? What do you think?

question: Our first annual report, must be thirty-five years ago now, I owned two stations, I wrote down a state- ment of purpose, that one day you would wake up to a Parrish radio station, read a Parrish paper at breakfast, catch our news on tele- vision during the day, and go to bed with one of our books or magazines and you would always be told the truth and in the bargain, have a good time.
answer: That's great! Wait 'til I show it to Bontecou.

question: ...Honey, you've got to go on... there's a time to sow and a time to reap, you sow now and forget about him... yeah, I liked him, I don't like him anymore... because you're my honey and anybody messes with you messes with me -- I'm on a plane in a minute... as soon as I get my phone in, you're my first call, that's a promise... where you going now?... good, hit the books, get that degree, one day we'll hang out a shingle together... you bet, honey... later. Good morning, I was talking kind of loud there, sorry.
answer: Not at all. It was fascinating.

question: Oh yeah? What was 'fascinating' about it?
My kid sister. She just broke up with her boyfriend and she's thinking about dropping out of law school.
Nothing to be sorry about. That's the way with men and women, isn't it?
Nothing lasts.
Why?
answer: I was just being agreeable, now I've got to explain why?

question: I'm not trying to sharpshoot you, but that 'nothing lasts' stuff, that's what was the trouble with Honey's guy. He was fooling around and Honey caught him at it. One girlfriend wasn't enough for him.
Damn right. Looking for her right now. Who knows? You might be her.
Everybody's a doctor around here. This apartment house is all green pajamas and slippers. The guy I'm waiting for to vacate is a doctor. What kind of doctor?
So if I needed a doctor, you could be it?
'Her'.
answer: Yes, I could. I have an office in the hospital.

question: -- This is my lucky day. I arrive in this big bad city and I not only find a doctor, a beautiful woman as well.
How 'bout another cup of coffee?
I'm all excited --
I thought it was great, I thought you and Big John would be like a couple of bulls in a china shop -- Instead it was --
answer: Like a marriage made in heaven?

question: Yes.
'Yes' is the answer to your question.
I believe you did.
I think you know --
Try. Because 'if you haven't tried, you haven't lived'.
What you were talking about.
answer: What is this? Who is this fucking guy?

question: Are you giving me orders?
No, you're not. You're trying to 'handle' the situation but this is the one situation you knew you never could handle.
answer: Where are you? Are you there?

question: It's enough now.
There's going to be plenty of time for that.
I think you know --
answer: Know what? Know what, goddammit! Come in.

question: Know what? Know what, goddammit! Come in.
answer: I've been buzzing you, Mr. Parrish. Are you all right?

question: Sure.
answer: Lunch is 'in' today, have you given it any thought --_

question: No. Nothing.
...It's kind of a pro bono job.
answer: 'Pro bono'. That means doing good -- Going to be doing good all your life?

question: I know what you're saying. Doesn't pay very well. Depends on the woman I marry. Maybe she'd like a bigger house, a better car, lotsa kids, college doesn't come cheap --
answer: You'd give up what you want for the woman you marry?

question: I would.
answer: You'll have a hard time finding a woman like that these days --

question: You never know. Lightning could strike.
Did I say something wrong?
answer: No, it was so right it scares me.

question: I've been thinking... I don't want you to be my doctor. Because I don't want you to examine me.
Because I like you so much. You have coffee here every morning, don't you? If I came by, could you give me the name of a doctor?
answer: Sure, I'll give you the name of a doctor. ...And I don't want to examine you.

question: Why not?
answer: Because I like you so much. Now I've got to go.

question: ...Music, I know how you love music, Daddy, and I want to have music that pleases you -- and of course doesn't put a thousand other people to sleep -- I've agonized over this and finally settled on Sidney Brown, twenty-four men, very eclectic, plus I'm feathering in a Latin sextet on their breaks - Tito Puente, Trini Lopez-zy, I forget their names --
I lay awake nights in a cold sweat, I want this party to be like some- thing Mom would have made for you, I want it to be perfect --
And you could care less --
answer: Oh, you couldn't be more wrong, sweetheart. I can' tell you how much I appreciate it and how I'm looking forward to it.

question: Good. Songs. What songs should Sidney -- Pancho and his six men we can forget about -- what songs do you think he should play?
Hello?
Where are you?
What is this, a joke, right? Some kind of elaborate practical joke? At my 40th reunion, we delivered a casket to the Class president's hotel room and --
I - I - uh --
answer: The great Bill Parrish at a loss for words? The man from whose lips fall 'rapture' and 'passion' and 'obses- sion'...all those admonitions about being 'deliberately happy', what there is no sense 'living your life without...', all the sparks and energy you give off, the rosy advice you dispense in round, pear-shaped tones --

question: What the hell is this? Who are you?
answer: Just think of millenniums multiplied by aeons compounded by infinity, I've been around that long, but it's only recently that your affairs here have piqued my interest. Call it boredom, the natural curiosity of me, the most lasting and significant element in existence has come to see you.

question: About what?
answer: I want to have a look around before I take you.

question: 'Take me'...? Where?
answer: It requires competence, wisdom, experience -- all those things they say about you in testimonials -- and you're the one.

question: 'The one' to do what?
answer: Show me around. Be my guide. And in return, you get...

question: Get what?
What the hell are you talking about?
I'm sorry --
answer: In return you'll receive minuets, days, weeks, I'm not going to go into details ... what matters is that I stay interested.

question: Yes what?
answer: 'Yes' is the answer to your ques- tion.

question: What question?
answer: Bill. Come on. The question. The question you've been asking yourself with increased regularity, at odd moments, panting through the extra game of handball, when you ran for the plane in Delhi, when you sat up in bed last night and hit the floor in the office this morning. The question that is in the back of your throat, choking the blood to your brain, ringing in the ears over and over as you put it to yourself --

question: The 'question' --
...Am I going to die?
Am I dreaming this? Are you a dream?
You're coming to 'take me'. What is that? Who the hell are you? You are --?
...Death.
Death!
You're not Death. You're just a kid in a jacket and a pair of pants.
answer: The jacket and the pair of pants came with the body I took. Let me ask your opinion. Do I blend in?

question: You want me to be your guide --?
I do? How long will you be staying?
answer: You should hope quite a while.

question: Yes. Thank you.
answer: This is crazy -- you're not going to eat dinner with us.

question: Bill, I am eating dinner with you. And your family. And that's what we're doing. It's not open for discussion. Nothing is. Don't you understand?
answer: Excuse me? Could I say something?

question: Of course.
Speak up, please.
answer: When I introduce you, if I say who you are, I don't think anyone will stay for dinner.

question: Is there any more to it?
Like 'Smith' or 'Jones --'
I get the feeling you've done some business before.
What side of the industry did you say you were on?
Joe sounds like a ringer, Bill. I have the feeling you guys got the broad strokes already. Need any help with the details?
...I'm here, aren't I? Wouldn't miss a loose end meeting. What's on the table for discussion? Party favors, flowers -- hi Dad, hi Drew --
We've met.
...I'm sorry, I'm a little discon- certed, that stuff between you and Susan -- uh -- threw me.
Shook me up. I mean that you knew her and everything --
answer: I didn't know her. The body I took knew her. The man she met in the coffee shop this morning. I - uh - took him.

question: So there's nothing between you and Susan?
I wish you had said something to me about staying here --
answer: It hadn't occurred to me until then. I was just having such a wonderful time -- Besides, isn't this what I'm here for?

question: No, I'm okay with this - uh - I think. So -- Bathroom...tub...towels, sauna --
Thank you. Would you like the man's name?
If there is anything else, don't hesitate --
How long have I got?
answer: You're putting me on the spot, Bill.

question: When you go, I go.
answer: That's the best I can do. ...but minute-by-minute, I find myself lingering.

question: ...I just saw my doctor, he told me everything was fine.
answer: Your doctor? Did your doctor say anything about a tiny, undetectable hole in your aorta? Did he mention an irreparab- ly weak vein in the further reaches of your famous brain? Were they any prognostications about the possibil- ilites of a fatal collision on a golf cart of suffocating in an avalanche on a skin vacation in Gstaad?

question: No --
answer: I hope you realize, Bill...in your office this morning, that was your time.

question: Closer than that. Well, thank you for letting me know.
And - uh - I guess, 'goodnight'.
...Miss Allison asked if you would like to have your dinner kept warm?
Very good, sir.
Yes, sir?
answer: Hello. I'm Joe Black. Nice to meet you.

question: Yes sir, Mr. Black, a pleasure.
You mean this, sir?
answer: 'Laura Scudder's Peanut Butter'. You like it?

question: I would say, sir, it is right up there with Jif and Skippy. But miles ahead of Peter Pan. Like a taste?
answer: Yes, I am. I thoroughly enjoyed this - uh - peanut butter. And I thoroughly enjoyed meeting you.

question: Yes, I am. I thoroughly enjoyed this - uh - peanut butter. And I thoroughly enjoyed meeting you.
I'm lost.
answer: -- Can't seem to escape you today.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: Hand me one of those, will you?

question: 'Big'?
answer: You appear at his side out-of-the- blue, stay at his house, eat dinner with his family, it's practically a first. You're in the red-hot center of big business and I thought you were a regular Joe.

question: I am Joe.
answer: Not the one I met this morning, hit- ting on me in as nice a way as I've been hit on in a long time, but the moment you find out I'm my Dad's daughter, you act like a stranger.

question: That is not my intention.
answer: What are your intentions? To make little dreams in coffee shops, turn a woman's head, and I don't mind admitting it was turned, I liked it, but ten hours later I feel like a fool. I don't get it. You, my father, here in this house, the cof- fee shop, it's making me upset, and I don't like being upset. Who are you anyway? And what are you eating?

question: Peanut butter.
answer: You act like you never had peanut butter before --

question: I haven't.
answer: -- What kind of childhood did you have?

question: Do you love Drew?
When you put your mouth to his, Susan, it seems a frequent thing.
answer: Drew is none of your damn business. Nor is where I put my mouth.

question: I'm sorry. Do you live here?
answer: No, Joe, I'm swimming here. Then I'm going home.

question: I guess what I'm trying to say is -- I'd like us to be friends.
I don't have any.
...I didn't mean to offend you at dinner. I'm not quite at home some- times with people. I get busy doing - uh - what I do, and I don't seem to have developed --
I have a certain function to per- form, and that seems to take all of my time. Bu sometimes - uh - I speculate - uh - I haven't left room for - uh - anything else.
answer: I'm sorry to say I know what you're saying.

question: Susan?
Did you know you have a wet spot on your shoulder?
Goodnight to you, Susan.
Yes?
answer: I think you want to go to the west wing. Through there.

question: Thank you.
Good morning, Bill.
answer: How are you? How're you feeling?

question: 'Feeling'? I feel fine. How do you feel?
answer: Um -- well, I didn't sleep too well. This is crazy. This is the left- field thing of all time. What do I do? What do I tell my family?

question: Oh, I wouldn't tell them anything, Bill. You'll ruin the good start we had last night. I felt as if I were being treated like a person. 'Joe' this and 'Joe' that - a nice smile - Quince passed me the rolls -- no 'rapture' or 'passion' or any of those mighty things you seem so intent on imparting, but I am cer- tain, should you - uh - say - uh - who I am - our adventure would end abruptly.
answer: What about my family? This 'adven- ture' involved only me, right?

question: And what?
answer: And I won't tell anyone who you are.

question: Sounds fair enough.
A 'deal'?
answer: You give your word, I give mine -- that we'll do what we say. It's a truth exchanged between two people.

question: Bill --
You've got a deal.
answer: Shake hands. You know, I got to thinking last night -- with you here, and seem- ingly occupied, how's your work going - uh - elsewhere?

question: When you were shaving this morning, you weren't just shaving, right?
You were hatching ideas, making plans, arriving at decisions, right?
So you understand the concept then. When you're busy here, your work, what your task is, is being executed elsewhere.
So you've grasped the idea. Con- gratulations. Now multiply it by infinity and take it to the depth of forever, and you still will have barely a glimpse of what I am talking about.
Yes, Bill.
answer: How about giving a guy a break?

question: Make an exception?
Not this.
answer: -- I don't deserve this. I'm still young, this is not my time --

question: That's what everybody says.
That's what everybody says.
I understand.
What do you mean?
answer: What's it like where I'm going?

question: Can you keep a secret?
So can I.
answer: Good morning, Jaime. I'm sorry, not today, Jaime. -- And call my family, I'd like them to come over for dinner tonight.

question: Good morning, Jaime. I'm sorry, not today, Jaime. -- And call my family, I'd like them to come over for dinner tonight.
answer: Didn't the family get together last night --?

question: Jennifer.
answer: Of course, Mr. Parrish. Right away.

question: Perhaps you would like to wait in my office --?
What I'm trying to say is this is a Board meeting and you are not a mem- ber of the Board.
answer: I'm sure you'll see to it that it won't be a problem.

question: Nice to see you. I didn't expect you, but certainly you can't get enough of a good thing.
The Board of Parrish Communications - is hereby called to order. Our sole order of business is an acceptance of John Bontecou's generous offer and --
answer: Do you have any more of these deli- cious cookies?

question: Anything else, Mr. Black? How about some water?
Hot or cold.
To review -- we're really crossing the 't's and dotting the 'i's here. Bill had a great and conclusive meeting with John Bontecou yester- day, all that remains for us is to put it to a vote.
...Sounds like you're not leaving much room for discussion.
answer: Sorry. I know it looks like I'm reversing my field.

question: That's your privilege, Bill. But given our needs, given the absolute necessity for growth, given the fu- ture, the truth is... joining John Bontecou is every bit as certain as - Death and Taxes.
Yes.
Yes.
It's just a saying, Mr. Black,
It doesn't matter.
answer: Then why did you bring it up?

question: You're not familiar with the phrase, "In this world, nothing is certain but Death and Taxes"?
Glad I could be of some help.
-- What's the deal here? Are you going to be breathing down my neck right 'til the very end?
...I'd like to be alone for a while.
Yes, I am. There's a research lib- rary on the fourth floor. Why don't you go down and read some magazines?
answer: You're not thinking of going some- where, are you, Bill?

question: Joe, could I ask you to take a walk? Buy a tie or something. I know I'll be seeing you.
Now I'd like to be alone.
Here -- this will hold you for a while.
Jennifer, give Mr. Black a map of the city.
answer: No thank you, Bill. I can manage.

question: No thank you, Bill. I can manage.
How nice you look. Is that your uniform?
Oh goodness, no.
answer: Then why are you here, Joe?

question: I came to see you.
answer: I don't have any time to see you now. I'm doing grand rounds and then I'm examining back-to-back patients until dinner and then --

question: Very well, I'll watch.
Whatever you do.
answer: That's impossible. I'm a doctor, I'm --

question: And I'll be a visitor.
Please. My momma's sicker'n he is.
No, Momma.
Obeah.
What you then?
You wait here'n to take us? Like you bus driver to dere?
Some spot you pick.
answer: I nuttin' to do wi' dat.

question: Make it go 'way.
Not dis pain. Dis pain tru an' tru. Make it go 'way.
Can, mistah. Take me to dat nex' place.
Make it time.
answer: Can't feel wi' de way tings gotta be, Easter.

question: Close your eyes, Easter.
answer: Go with her. I'll be right there.

question: She's in a great deal of pain.
Some.
answer: Don't apologize. There's nothing to be sorry for -- every hospital should have someone like you.

question: Thank you. I'm so very glad to be here.
Well, I could come again some other time.
Not now.
answer: I have to go, I'm sorry to say --

question: Be sorry for nothing.
Good-bye, Susan. Are you going to eat your lunch
Excellent. What is it?
answer: Cold lamb sandwich with cilantro. A little Coleman's mustard.

question: Truly - uh - splendid.
answer: Glad you like it. My wife turned me onto cold lamb sandwiches. Joan -- that was my wife --

question: Uh-huh.
answer: Cold lamb sandwiches -- not as chewy as roast beef, not as boring as chicken. She knew stuff like that.

question: And more.
Well...I don't know.
answer: I thought you'd heard a trillion times --

question: This part I'm interested in.
answer: She had on this little blue suit -- with a little white collar that had little red piping on it --

question: No.
Sit down, Drew.
answer: Before I do -- I was hoping we might be alone, Bill.

question: Joe and I have no secrets from each other.
Why?
answer: I was hired, you told me, to help bring Parrish Communications into the 21st Century. This merger is the vehicle --

question: Joe, cut it out. And you too, Drew.
answer: I thought this was practically a done deal --

question: Well now it's undone, okay? Forget Bontecou! Scrub him! I'm tired of his fancy name and his fancy offer. I'm not going for it.
Why, at this juncture, are you letting yourself be so concerned by business matters?
answer: I don't want anybody buying up my life's work and turning it into something it wasn't meant to be. A man wants to leave something behind. And he wants it left behind the way he made it. And he wants it to be run the way he run it -- with a sense of honor, of dedication, of truth. Okay?

question: Okay.
answer: And I don't need your goddamn permis- sion either! You! Drew! I don't need anyone to tell me how to run my life.

question: ...I read you all the way on the Bontecou thing, and I know where you're coming from. And I'm with you a hundred and one percent.
But I've got to tell you, if mergers are in the wild, I've got some great prospects I've developed. I want to talk to you about them next week.
Yeah. Or the week after.
answer: No, anything is possible. It's up to Joe.

question: Did you know twenty-six members of your rifle company are coming?
From the Korean War.
Whatever it was, they'll be here. We sent out invitations to everyone, plane tickets included -- the RSVP's are amazing. A few of them we didn't hear from, and some of them are dead, of course --
You know, we're going to give this party for you whether you like it or not.
answer: I like it. I like it. I'm sorry I don't seem more appreciative.

question: ...I know you're down, but you know when you're down, Drew, there's no place to go but up.
Never mind Bontecou. I've got some other merger possibilities up my sleeve, and I'm putting them to see old man.
We'll do it together. I'll clue you in. Timing's got to be right. The old man says it's up to Joe.
answer: 'It's up to Joe'? Those were his words?

question: Yeah.
Yeah, that's what he said.
I thought so, too. Joe's a neat guy.
I wanted to apologize, Susan --
answer: I thought you said 'Be sorry for nothing'.

question: Well, now I am sorry. For intruding on you this afternoon.
answer: It wasn't an intrusion. And if it was, it turned out to be welcome.

question: I appreciate you --
I mean I appreciate that.
I was a little abrupt with you this afternoon, Drew. Forgive me. I want you to know I value your advice.
You're competitive soul, Drew. That's what makes you a great addi- tion to the money. Joe is just... around.
Please. Don't worry about him. And above all, don't antagonize him.
answer: Boss's orders, huh? I'm great at following them. And I think I'll start right now.

question: Why do you love peanut butter so much?
I adore things like that....food I can't do without. Don't you?
It comforts you, doesn't it?
I'm very concerned about the woman you attended to today.
Has her pain abated?
answer: We're doing what we can for her. But it doesn't look good.

question: I'm sorry to hear that.
But I know she's grateful for the care you're giving her.
answer: Is this a state secret or are we being excluded just for the fun of it?

question: Why did you go to the hospital?
You were just curious?
About Susan?
answer: I wouldn't put it that way.

question: What way would you put it?
How about you telling me? When I ask a simple question, I expect a straight answer. That's what I'm used to. Anybody who doesn't give it to me, I fire.
answer: Are you going to fire me, Bill?

question: ...See you tomorrow night.
answer: Include me out. I've had enough of the conversations.

question: You don't mean that. You wouldn't disappoint Daddy --
answer: Daddy'll do fine. Besides, he's got Joe. And so do you.

question: Drew, you're out of line.
answer: That may be. But I don't like the fucker. I don't like the way he looks at you and talks to you. And vice versa.

question: Sorry, but I like the way he looks and talks to me. And vice versa. Okay?
answer: No, not okay. I thought we had a good thing going here. It shows you never know.

question: Well... goodnight.
How long have you been standing there?
answer: I don't like the way Drew spoken to you. But I feel better about it now because of the way you spoke back.

question: Tell me about yourself, Joe. Who you are. What you're doing with my father.
Because guys who never say anything about themselves are always married.
Girlfriend?
Gay?
Then tell me, Joe, how come a man as attractive, intelligent, well- spoken ,diffident in the most sed- uctive way, and yet powerful, is all alone in this world?
Where are you going?
'To bed'?
That was wonderful.
answer: Yeah, it's good to get together.

question: Do you mind if I raise a little caution flag?
What is the nature of your interest in Joe?
answer: Well, remember how you told me about "lightning striking"? The nature of it's in there somewhere.

question: I won't say you may be getting onto shaken ground --
I don't think this is the lightning you are looking for. Drew's a good man. I know I didn't seem to be completely in his corner before, but I've come to appreciate --
answer: Now we love Drew and Joe in verbo- ten? What's going on?

question: Nothing.
answer: When you say 'nothing' that way, it's not nothing.

question: Then what is it?

...I know you're all as uncomfor- table as I am to be meeting without Bill, but I got a call last night from John Bontecou. Not only is he still interested, he is sweetening his offer. Although it pains me to say it, in my opinion Bill Parrish dealt with us peremptorily in dismissing any deal with Bontecou. Therefore, I'm sorry to say that if we are to exam- ine this new offer responsibly as the Board of Directors of Parrish Communications, we must do so with- out its Chairman. Oh yes, there is one additional element
Bill's birthday is the day after tomorrow. There is a provisory by- law in our charter. Per the discre- tion of the Board, Corporate off- icers can be retired at age sixty- five.
answer: You're taking this too far, Drew.

question: Am I not obligated to?
answer: You're building this thing up too much, Drew. He's had advisors be- fore. Nobody tells Bill what to do.

question: Thank you for coming.

I hope you'll respect its nature -- What we're trying to do here is gather our thoughts -- in light of Bill's rejection of Bontecou's offer -- and make an appropriate presenta- tion to him as to how we think the company might proceed. Won't you share with our Board the information you gave me last night?
answer: Well, I'm happy to tell you I've got good news. As I was telling Drew, I've been making a little hay while the Bontecou sun was shining -- two, possibly three new and boiling hot prospects for merger.

question: How did Bill react to the leads you've developed?
-- But he was concerned about the timing?
answer: The timing -- yes. He says it's up to Joe.

question: 'It's up to Joe'?
What is this?
Who's Annie?
answer: From La Rosette, only the greatest pastry chef in America. This is orange, from real Seville oranges. Lemon, on a mille-feuille crust, a little on the fanciful. And a while, nothing like a good old white cake, vanilla, with Angel food but some maroons shavings thrown in.

question: I don't like cake.
Oh, the goddam party --
The vodka. What'd I tell you?
answer: Cirrhosis of the liver is the fifth leading killer of adult Western males.

question: I didn't know that.
answer: On the other hand, Winston Churchill drank a bottle of cognac a day and lived until he was ninety-one.

question: You're an original, Joe. A little hard to figure, maybe...
answer: And you're a nice man, Quince.

question: Thanks.
Sorry to intrude, Bill, but we've got a bit of a crisis downtown -- it's not something we could talk about on the phone.
answer: What is there to say? They know what John Bontecou is -- and if they didn't, they know now.

question: Yes, you made your feeling abun- dantly clear. Now they want to do the same with theirs.
If I read this Board right now, they want you to accept Bontecou's offer.
What do you think the Board is going to say when I tell them that?
With all due respect, you damn well better care because if you try to stonewall them again, there'll be blood on the floor.
Yours.
answer: I'm feeling real uncomfortable right now because the guy who reports to me is threatening me.

question: I'm just giving you the truth. There was a time when William Parrish liked the truth.
answer: I think it's time you went home, Drew.

question: Almost.
What an angry fellow.
Please. We don't need to talk about Drew.
I love your smell.
Thank you.
-- Could you?
answer: Never tried, 'til now. Joe, may I kiss you?

question: Why, yes. Thank you.
You're welcome.
Yes?
answer: I don't know who you are.

question: Well...I'm -- uh, Joe. And you're Susan. And I - uh - have this weak feeling in my knees --
answer: And is your heart beating strangely?

question: Faster. And I want the scent from underneath your ears and the taste of your lips and the touch of your tongue to stay with me -- forever.
answer: I have to go home. Goodnight, Daddy.

question: Hello, Bill.
answer: Hello. Would you like to join me, Quince and Allison for a nightcap?

question: Um -- not right now.
Good morning, Mr. Parrish.
The Board is waiting.
Didn't you call a Board meeting?
Good morning.
answer: Did you want to have a cup of coffee or something, Bill?

question: I don't think so. Do you?
answer: To get to the point, we have re- ceived new information from John Bontecou concerning his desires for this company to merge with his, and we wanted to set the details before you.

question: That's it?
answer: Bontecou wants a quick response and --

question: The answer is no, quick enough for you?
answer: Don't you want to hear the details?

question: I'm not interested in the details. And I'm not interested in the big picture either. What I am inter- ersted in is how my Board got conven- ed behind my back, is entertaining a further proposal from a man whom it offends me to do business with, moreover has the audacity to present this to me like a prize fish, and I am expected to clap for it like a performing seal. No, thank you.
answer: So I am to understand from your re- sponse that you do not want to hear the details of Bontecou's offer?

question: Yes, you are to understand that, and now may I ask you a question?

Doesn't need to. Today, tomorrow, a week from now -- 'a week from now', who can think about a week from now -- the answer is going to be the same -- a loud, unmistakable, all-inclusive, airtight -- 'No'.
answer: Before we do, while we're here, there is a second question the Board would like a response to, a far simpler one.

question: I've already introduced Mr. Black to you all.
answer: But who is he? What are his creden- tials? What is his relationship to you?

question: In English, please.
answer: Mandatory retirement upon our Chairman's sixty-fifth birthday.

question: Thank you for allowing me to save face, Drew.
answer: The other motion before us is the acceptance of John Bontecou's offer to merge this corporation with Bontecou International --

question: ...It's not over, 'til it's over.
answer: Please, Eddie, no 'Fat Lady Sings" shit.

question: I still sense some doubt in this group, we could turn it around. You'll be up in the country?
answer: Yes, the big 'celebration' of my mandatory retirement birthday. You're an honored guest, Eddie.

question: What have you done? You've gotten the old man fired!
answer: That we did. Thanks to you. He was wobbling, mind you, but you stupid the coup de grace.

question: I'm going to put a stop to this!
answer: Quince, you can't unscramble scrambled eggs.

question: But I didn't mean to do it!
answer: The train's left the station, pal, and you're aboard. Would you like to hear the silver lining? Check that, gold. I've been working with John Bontecou all along. We had a game plan -- acquire Parrish Communications then break it apart and peddle it piece-by-piece to the highest bidder. I set it up for him, he smacks it out of the park.

question: I don't want to get rich this way -- I'm going to expose you.
answer: Go right ahead. Tell William Parrish how you betrayed him at a secret Board meeting. And tell Allison how you got her father fired -- and he lost his company.

question: I'm sorry, Bill --
What's okay?
answer: Just a manner of speaking. What 'okay' is, it's 'okay' it's over. We've got bigger fish to fry, don't we, Joe?

question: 'Fish'?
answer: Never mind. I'm tired. I'm going to take a nap.

question: I'm not hungry.
You're here?
I just thought I'd drop by, scrounge a little lunch, I was in the neigh- borhood --
Just throw it on the chair.
He must be tired -- this Bontecou thing --
answer: Yes, he's tired. I believe so.

question: No, not anymore. Are you?
Maybe it's the draft through the door. It's so wonderful to make love to you. It's like making love to some- one who has never made love before.
Did you like making love to me?
More than you love peanut butter?
Where are you going?
For how long?
answer: Oh, I hope a long, long time.

question: Me, too.
It will come to us.
Hello, Bill.
I'm sorry to hear that.
Yes, I saw you see me.
answer: Well, you're at the wrong place at the wrong time with the wrong woman.

question: I'll be the judge of that.
With all due respect, Bill, I'm not asking your permission.
answer: Well, you goddam well should. You walk into my life, give me the worst news a guy can get, have me dancing on the heads of pins with my busi- ness and with my family, and now you're spooning with my daughter.

question: 'Spooning'?
answer: Yes, and stop repeating everything I sai, and turning it into a question. Spooning, fooling around, God knows what. You arrive on the scene -- why you picked me, I still don't under- stand --

question: I picked you for your verve, your excellence, and for your ability to - how shall I say - instruct. You've lived a first-rate life. And I find it eminently usable.
I'm only following the Parrish bywords. Looking for that 'ounce of excitement', that 'whisper of a thrill' -- What there is no sense living your life without. You know what I mean, Bill.
answer: You're violating the laws of the universe.

question: This universe?
answer: Any universe that exists or ever existed. You may be the pro, Joe. But I know who you are. And you're all fucked up.

question: I don't like your tone, and I don't like your references.
answer: And I don't give a shit.

question: May I remind you this is not just a dispute with a putative suitor, this is me. So watch it...Bill.
answer: Cut the 'Bill' crap out -- you sonofabitch.

question: I told you, 'watch it'. Dr. Parrish. Oh.
answer: Mistah Bad News. 'Bout time you show up.

question: Don' be facety, woman.
answer: None facety, mistah. You come for me? Dat's good news.

question: No, I come to see Doctor.
answer: Doctor? What could be wrong wit' you?

question: Nuthin'.
answer: Oh, you come to see Doctor Lady?

question: Yes.
Mine, too.
Yah.
I am.
She knows how she feel.
Don' need you okayin'.
answer: Schoolboy tings is you head. Badness for you, badness for her, badness for me, lyin' here tumor, big as breadfruit, poison my inners an' waiting.

question: Brung you flowers and all I gettin's facety back.
answer: Only flowers I wan' see's one's over my peaceful self restin' in the dutty.

question: Can do no right by people. Come to take, you wan' to stay, leave you stay, you wan' to go. Rahtid!
answer: You not in you right place, mistah.

question: But I not lonely here. Somebody want me here.
answer: It nice it happen to you. It like you came to Cat Island and you had a holiday, sun didn't burn you red, just brown, sleep no mosquito eat you, rum no poung you head nex' day. But trut' is, dat bound to happen, you stay long enough. So tak dat nice picture home wi' you, but don' be fooled. We lonely here mostly, too. If we lucky, we got some nice pictures.

question: Hello, honey.
Joe?
I don't know.
answer: Because I was sitting in a staff meeting, incredibly bored, my mind kept wandering and the only place it landed was -- Joe.

question: I don't understand.
answer: Love. Passion. Obsession, all those things you told me to wait for. Well, they've arrived.

question: This is crazy --
answer: Why? A man appears at your side, almost never leaves it, you clearly trust him, depend on him, I sense you value him deeply, why aren't those things good enough for me?

question: You don't know anything about Joe --
answer: What are you afraid of, Dad? That I'll fall head over heels for Joe -- well, I have -- as you did with Mom. That's always been standard, whether you like or not.

question: Susan, I don't think Joe is going to be with us long.
I don't know, I can't say --
answer: C'mon! The guy's working with you. You always know chapter and verse about everyone who works --

question: In this case, I can't. I - uh -- I just can't help you. I only would tell you -- that with Joe, you are on very, very dangerous ground.
I don't care if you love him! I'm telling you he's no good for you!
answer: Of course not, Daddy. I'm sorry.

question: Why are you giving me money? I am who I am. I cannot change. That's impossible. You're wasting your money. I couldn't change even if I wanted to. Uh --
-- I have the feeling that, all in all, what I made this voyage for -- has served its purpose.
answer: What are you saying, that it's time to go?

question: You are?
Good. Tomorrow, after the party.
Excuse me. Eddie?
answer: Yeah - Bill - How are you? You okay?

question: Fine, fine. Big doing up here. Why are you still down here?
answer: The Board's working through the weekend, trying up the loose ends this damn thing. But I want to give it one more try, I'm still holding out some hope.

question: Eddie, hold out all the hope you want but, I promise you, it's hope- less, it's over. Come on up, let's get drunk, if I had your shoulder to lean on I might actually enjoy this --
answer: No, I'm going to stay down here, keep my finger in the dike and maybe by Monday, the waters could recede.

question: If you're trying to show me lay- down-in-front-of-the-bus loyalty, forget it.
answer: Sorry, Bill, have a drink, eat your cake, blow out the candles and make a wish. Talk to you Monday. Okay?

question: Okay, Eddie -- anyway, thanks for the memory.
answer: Hi, Daddy, what do you think?

question: It's starting to grow on me. But what do the 'B' and 'P' mean?
answer: The fountain is the Caspian Sea and the Sea is serving up caviar. The 'B's for Beluga, the 'P' for Petrossian. Of course, they also stand for 'Bill' and for 'Parrish'.

question: Do they, m'dear?
answer: -- Plus we've got a baritone with a balalaika coming from The Russian Tea Room. I've dressed him in a Cossack shirt and he'll sing Nelson Eddy songs.

question: You are amazing. Why, oh why, Allison, are you doing all this?
answer: I do it because I love you. Because everybody I loved you. Mommy -- wher- ever she is -- Susan, Quince, the people who work for you, everybody who's ever known you.

question: Yeah? And what about my enemies?
answer: They respect you. Isn't that a kind of love?

question: I haven't been the father to you that --
I wasn't going to say --
answer: But that's what you were thinking. And that's okay. Because I know you love me. Not like it is with Susan, the way your eyes light up when she comes in the room and the way she always gets a laugh out of you, as opposed to me when I walk in a room and that look comes over your face, "What does she want now?"

question: Hey, there's lots to come. A little excess -- like you love. You know, darling, this is going to be a wonderful party.
Give me a Seagrams and '7'.
answer: I'm afraid this is a wine bar, Mr. Quince.

question: Okay, give me a bottle of wine.
Both.
C'mon, have a drink. You look like you need one bad as me.
answer: Do I? I'm a little confused.

question: Confused, huh? About what?
'Love'? Oh, man, I've got troubles of my own.
Oh yes, I do.
I was a world-class loser and she was a happy, little rich girl -- and for some reason she took me in.
Because there's nothing we don't know about each other and it's okay. I mean the deeper, darkest secrets -- they don't matter.
Yeah, it's like you know every inch of each other's souls -- and then you're free.
Free to love each other. Com- pletely. Totally. No fear.
answer: Oh yes, you are one of my favorites.

question: What would you say if you knew it was me who brought down Bill Parrish? I told Drew and the Board that Bill depended on you. Drew led me on, but I had no business telling him in the first place. He was setting up Bill from day one. Drew and Bontecou are going to chop up the company and sell it off for parts. Bontecou was outside, Drew was Mr. Inside. And I was the fool who made it all happen. Oh God, what do I do?
answer: Go to Bill Parrish and tell him everything. He'll forgive you.

question: You think so? How do you know?
answer: Because that's the kind of man Bill Parrish is.

question: Well, maybe... I guess you know him better than anybody.
Do you think I should wait to tell him 'till after the party?
No.
answer: I like you in a black tie.

question: I love you in an evening gown.
answer: It beats a surgical, doesn't it?

question: Yes. Your father and I, our time together has come to an end.
Well -- I --
answer: And you can't tell me who you are.

question: I can tell you the when part. Tonight.
No worse than it gets for me. I'm in love with a woman whom I don't want to leave.
We know so little about each other --
answer: We know all that we need to know --

question: But there's so much to tell you --
Will it?
answer: Lightning struck. We caught it in a bottle. Don't let it out. I want to be with you, Joe --

question: What will we do?
'Love will find out the way'?
I believe that, don't you?
answer: Yes, that's why I said it.

question: Come in, Joe -- I want to thank you -- okay, Bill?
Joe knew the whole story. I told him. It was his idea that I come clean. I mean I wanted to come clean but he gave me a pair of balls, you know what I mean?
answer: Yes, I believe I do. No, I'm out of business, right, Quince? However I do have some unfinished business -- with Drew. Get him out here. Get him on the chopper and get him out here to- night. I want to tell this guy how I feel about him face-to-face.

question: All in all, what Bill wants to do is build the golden bridge to Drew with no hard feelings.
answer: You think Drew will go for it?

question: Quince, I've got confidence in you.
Thanks.
What the hell do you care?

You 'want to know', I'll tell you. You're looking at a man who tonight is not about to walk through the Valley of the Shadow of Death, he's galloping into it. And the same time, the business he built with his own hands and his own head is being commandeered by a couple of cheap pirates. And, oh yes, I almost forgot, my daughter's fallen in love with Death.
answer: -- And I'm in love with your daughter.

question: Say again?
answer: I'm in love with your daughter, and I'm taking her with me tonight.

question: You're what?
answer: I think you heard me, Bill.

question: You're not taking Susan anywhere. And what the hell does that mean anyway?
Susan is my daughter, she has a wonderful life ahead of her and you're going to deprive her of it and you're telling me you're sorry? Well, I'm sorry, apology not accepted.
answer: I love her, Bill. She is all that I ever wanted, and I've never wanted for anything because I've never wanted anything before, if you can understand.

question: How perfect for you -- to take whatever you want because it pleases you. It's not love --
Some aimless infatuation in which, for the moment, you feel like in- dulging. It's missing everything that matters.
Trust, responsibility, taking the weight, for your choices and feel- ings and spending the rest of your life living up to them. And above all, not hurting the object of your love.
Multiply it by infinity and take it to the death of forever and you will still have barely a glimpse of what I am talking about.
Well, they're mine now.
answer: Susan wants to come. She says she's in love with me.

question: With you?! Who is 'you'? Did you tell her who you are?
Does she know where she's going?
answer: I don't like what you're saying.

question: I don't expect you to.

I certainly hope so -- I loved Susan from the moment she was born, and I love her now, and every minute in between, and what I dream of is a man who will discover her and she will discover a man who will love her, who is worthy of her, who is of this world, of this time and has the grace and compassion and fortitude to walk beside her as she makes her way through this beautiful thing called life.
answer: Are you telling me I can't be part of it?

question: Hello, Joe. What'd you know?
answer: There is something I do want to tell you --

question: But you can't.
And I said you'd have a hard time finding a woman like that.
-- That was the place... and you were the guy.
You want me to wait for you, you'll be back --
answer: Don't you know, that's what I want more than anything.

question: You said before you couldn't tell me who or where, only the 'when' -- Is when now?
That felt like a goodbye.
But you're not. You're somewhere else. You're someone else -- Tell me you love me -- tell me you love me now --
answer: I love you now, I'll love you always --

question: Hold me --
-- Yes?
answer: Thank you for loving me. ...We should think about getting started, Bill.

question: Thank you.
Come in.
answer: -- I got him. The chopper's two minutes away.

question: This is damn big of Bill, I also think it's smart.
answer: He had no choice. You're a formidable adversary.

question: He said that?
answer: Well, you've got him by the short- hairs.

question: Hi, Bill, happy birthday --
I don't know where you get that idea -- the Board agreed --
answer: The Board didn't know you're a mole who burrowed inside so you could bury us all.

question: I told you to shut up.
He is --
answer: I'll take it from here -- I am --

question: -- An IRS man.

The Treasury Department asked my cooperation in his undercover investigation of John Bontecou. They were convinced that Bontecou, on past deals, had structured his mergers and acquisitions in sus- picious and complicated ways so as to evade paying the taxes he is liable for. The IRS wanted to go after him, and this deal offered them the opportunity. I agreed to cooperate.

Moreover, Agent Joe Black here -- of course that's not his real name -- smelled out your involvement, Drew. He developed evidence you were working both sides of the fence. Unfortunately, that's known as a conflict of interest --
An offense --
I think I'd like to talk to my lawyer --
answer: No lawyers, Drew. We're going to offer you a deal.

question: And what do I get?
answer: You get not to go to jail.

question: You're talking through your hat. You're offering a deal because you've got no proof.
answer: Proof? We've got plenty of proof.

question: I thought I was going to sneak away tonight...
I'm having a helluva time.
answer: You were right about Joe, he is going somewhere --

question: I'm sorry.
Yes, but --
I want you to know how much I love you. That you've given a meaning to my life that I had no right to expect, and that no one can ever take from me.

No -- I love you so much and I want you to promise me something. I don't want you to ever worry about me. If anything should happen, I'm going to be fine and everything's going to be all right. -- And I have no regrets.
That's why it's okay.
It's a good feeling, isn't it?
I'm still here. Would you like to dance with me, Susan?
If you don't mind dancing with an old fogey like me.
answer: Oh, Dad, you're not old. You'll never be old.

question: You go ahead, honey, I'm going to catch my breath.
Thank you.
I guess you have your reasons.
Now that we have a moment, would you mind if I expressed my gratitude for what you did for Susan?
answer: I wouldn't worry about it, Bill. These things have a way of working out.

question: Don't blow smoke up my ass, you'll ruin my autopsy.
Joe...?
Where did you go?
answer: I don't know -- y'know, I don't know -- it's all blurred up and hazy. And would y'know what I mean if I said I don't think it's worth figuring out?

question: That's it?
answer: Well, I don't know what else to say. It's a helluva party --

question: You think so?
answer: Yeah...and you're the prettier thing here.
